Our law gives the juvenile judge all kind of authority.
The law says -- our statute says that the juvenile judge when the person is arrested on a complaint, he shall be brought before the Court.
And the law says that the juvenile judge may release into the parents.
He may place him in the foster home. He may place him in the hands of a probation officer or he may detain them.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How do you explain that seeming anomaly?
It's the same boy isn't it, 14-year-old boy.
The offense is the same regardless of its technical designation under the -- as a juvenile offense or an adult offense, the Act he is charged with is the same Act namely the murder of Mrs. Willard.
Now, how do you count for the fact that as a juvenile, he was kept in children's file and immediately, he is given the status of an adult and he is out on bail?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Because the only thing I know is that that's what our statute serves, to judge.
The only thing I know is that that's what the statute says that our judge shall do.
Now, if it was to be argued that the Court maybe abused its discretion and not releasing him to his parents or somebody else.

That's what's on the record but the judge you said that at the time and on these motions for bails, the judge said that this was not a popularity contest, and he had a duty to protect the people of the State of Ohio and he owed a duty to this boy.
That's what the judge said.
That was what the judge said at that time.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: The Common Pleas judge who released him on bail after the transfer --

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Could he have?

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Did he?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: After the transfer of Buddy Lynn Whittington from the Juvenile Court to the Adult Court and the Common Pleas judge acquired jurisdiction over him, didn't he?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And he was released on bail?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: He was released but the bond was fixed by the Juvenile Court.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: By the Juvenile Court.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: By the Juvenile Court.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: What I want to know is the Juvenile Court judge didn't have anymore authority under the -- after the boy became an adult as a technical matter, did he?
And he had when the boy was a juvenile.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Well, our statute says that if he transfers him to the Common Pleas Court that he must fix bond.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: He must --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So he had no discretion.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: He had no discretion then.
I don't think he had any discretion at all because the statute --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Even though he is transferred on what turned out to be a first degree murder charge.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Well, you'll understand.
It is true that the specific Act that he was charged within a Juvenile Court if it were not the Adult, would constitute second degree murder.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I understand that.
That's the way the complaint read.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And then he got the benefit of the Juvenile Court procedure as transferred to the Adult Court, released on bail which had been denied to him as -- when he was getting the benefit of being treated as a juvenile and then he was indicted for first degree murder.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's right.
And of course under the indictment for first degree murder, he is not subject to bail in the State of Ohio.
Now, let me say one thing further here, that this boy – a hearing after this boy being a delinquent, was held on September the 2nd of 1966.
This was a very short period of time after the warrant had been issued for his arrest and of course there were --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Excuse me Mr. Morehart but may I ask, we don't understand that you're able to present more evidence to the Grand Jury than you're able to produce before the juvenile judge.
Is this what explains the indictment for first degree?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That is true.
We knew some things at the time the Grand Jury witness had did, that was not known at that time that this affidavit was filed -- complaint was filed in the Juvenile Court.
That is correct sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Was the petition of the Juvenile Court to transfer Buddy Lynn Whittington to the Adult Court?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: A petition to do so?

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, how did that come about?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: This came about because the discretion given to the Juvenile Court.
The Juvenile Court under 2151.26 which you quote earlier of the Juvenile Court Act says, that if the Court finds that he has committed in that which would be a felony that's committed by an adult.

After he makes a thorough investigation and after he causes a mental and physical examination to be made, he shall then transfer at the Common Pleas Court or he may retain it and dispose of it as a juvenile.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I understand that but are you now telling us that nobody, no state official requested the judge to transfer Buddy Lynn Whittington from a status from the jurisdiction of the Juvenile Court to the Adult Court?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No sir.
I'll tell you that that's true.
I don't know of anyone.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Why didn't the judge transfer him before?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: He couldn't do so.
He was restrained from doing so by the Courts of Appeal.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: During that entire period?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's right.
That's true.
You see this from the time that this was heard on September 2nd until April, this had been in the Court of Appeals and it also been in the Supreme Court of the State of Ohio.

And after the Supreme Court refuse then to take jurisdiction and hear it on its merit that the Supreme Court of the State of Ohio, they granted a further extension of 20 days time and which tied the hands of the juvenile judge as far as binding was concerned.
And it was only when this Court refused to issue a further stay of execution that the juvenile judge was permitted to act --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Was the juvenile judge's finding of delinquency presented to the Grand Jury?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: You went before the Grand Jury made an independent case.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's true.
That is true.
The juvenile judges finding -- it cannot be considered in any other Court under our law.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And what he found the Buddy Lynn Whittington committed this act and then he ordered it instead of -- he ordered him to go to the --

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Juvenile Diagnostic Research Center.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- which is an additional proceeding to finding him over.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And while he was there, the appeal was taken.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's right.
The appeal before this Court right now.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You're suggesting that if there hadn't been an appeal at that moment and then he had come back to -- he had come back to Diagnostic Center, the judge would have found him over then.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: He would have ruled on it one way or the other.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now is your order to bind over appealable in your state?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Yes it is.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that a final order in your appeal?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I think that it is and I maintain.
And I have maintained in my brief that the order appeal from here is not a final order.
And I argue that in the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let's assume that an appeal had not been taken until Buddy can get back to the Diagnostic Center and he had been bound over.
And then there was an appeal.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the appeal was to challenge the order to bind over.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, would you suggest that what questions then would have been relevant or what questions could have been opened?
Wouldn't the same questions that had been opened that are now here?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's true.
I think the finding of under our statute it makes the finding of the juvenile judge that a person is delinquent.
It is an appealable order.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think that even though the finding that he committed this act and the finding that he is delinquent are made only as a preliminary to binding over?
Could it be that -- let's assume that some -- let's assume that he was not permitted cross-examination for example at that theory.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, if there was an appeal of the order to bind over after it was entered and it was challenged in the Ohio of course on the basis that they then proceed -- that the denial of procedure of due process in those proceedings.
Would that kind of a point be open in your Ohio court?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Yes sir.
That is true.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And open here if they brought it up here.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I think that is true.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that -- is that really quite -- the order now has been entered, has it?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's true.
But it is not before this Court because the appeal was taken before, you see.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Taken before the entry of that binding?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That is true that's why I say -- it was not fine order from the Court of Appeals but the Court of Appeals wouldn't listen.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, how long after the review was sought here was a bind of order --

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: After the review was sought here?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Just as soon as this Court refused to issue a state of execution further, the Juvenile Court then had a hearing and bound him over.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well now, before we agreed to review this case, I forgot what date that was.
Could anyone tell us about this bind over order?
Could you tell us the opposition for the petition for review?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I don't know where to -- I forget what was said there that -- I don't remember.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But in any event, no one sought to appeal the binding rule.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Yes they did.
It's still pending in the Court of Appeals of our county.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that order has been appealed.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that's the one you say that if it were brought on that, we can review and get to the same questions that the petitioner now reads.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: In my opinion, that is a final order.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Except -- perhaps -- Maybe some of those questions might come up but at least we would have jurisdiction to review that order.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I think that is true.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now let's see, you say that the appeal from the bind over order pending in what Court?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: In the Court of Appeals of our county, the Fifth District Court of Appeals, Fairfield County.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And that has not been --

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That has been stayed pending the outcome of this case.
In fact, there are three appeals in this case pending in the Court of Appeals of Fairfield County.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You may now recite it.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What are they?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: One is an appeal from the bind over.
The second one is an appeal for the failure of the County's Court to dismiss the indictment.
And the third one is the refusal of the Common Pleas Court to fix bond on the first degree murder charge.
Those three appeals are pending in the Court of Appeals at the present time.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So he is presently incarcerated?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Yes he is.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: After indictment he was --

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: His bail was cancelled.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: His bail was cancelled because he was indicted for first degree murder.
And that is not bailable under the laws of our state at the present time.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Is every indictment for first degree murder appealable?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No, an indictment is not.
I do not believe so.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: What is more than happening in the indictment and the arrest?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Nothing.
In fact, he has not even fled to the --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: And how could that be possible to be a final judgment with the meaning of our statute?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I don't think that it is.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I thought you said there's a motion to dismiss the indictment but it was denied.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: There is a motion to dismiss.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And there's an appeal from the denial of the motion to dismiss.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Yes, a question -- that's the final order but the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Why is there a motion to dismiss and the denial of that motion?

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I misunderstood you.
I thought you said that that would be a final judgment.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No, no, I do not think so sir.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I am sorry.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You used the bind over to --

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's right.
I consider the bind over under our statutes of being the final order -- an appeal.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: MThat isn't here.
It's still in the Ohio Court.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's right.
That's in the Court of the --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: The bind over be it more than just an -- the result of an arraignment of the preliminary hearing holding it -- I don't understand how you distinguish between those two, between the arrest under the indictment and the bind over order.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I distinguish it on this basis, sir.
As you know or may not know but in our state you cannot appeal in a criminal case from a jury verdict.
The appeal is from the judgment and sentence of the Court.
Now, you may have several intermediate --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: What finally sees a federal question -- final judgment in the federal sense?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: We're concerned with a federal meaning of the word final.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Yes, I think that is true and I --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Otherwise we don't have jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Well, I think that this is what we're arguing here that there is in that jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But I'm talking about that why you think there would be a final judgment in case of the bind over because nothing has happened there except an indictment and the under arrest.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: There's nothing more after the bind over for the Juvenile Court to do.
You see, he is disposed off the manner.
He is bounded over to Common Pleas Court or he has made other disposition.
Suppose for instance that he had not bounded over to the Common Pleas Court which he did not have to do, he could then do number of other things.
He could place him on probation under our law or he could sentence him to the Youth Commission.
Now if he is sentencing to the Youth Commission, he loses jurisdiction.
Our Juvenile Court does under our law.
He loses jurisdiction. The Youth Commission, the Ohio Youth Commission can turn him absolutely scratch free within 30 days if they want to do that.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Well, there's nothing more that the Juvenile Court can do now in this case.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's true when he binds him over, to my opinion, that's a final order.

He is through but he was not through when he made -- when this entry went on because he ordered him to the -- which he was required to do for physical and mental examination and for investigation and the causes continue --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Excuse me.
I beg your pardon.
Your Ohio Supreme Court entertained an appeal I suppose.
They have some requirement of finality.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Your Ohio Supreme Court entertained on appeal from the precise judgment or order or whatever it is that we have for us, is that right?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: They didn't entertain the appeal.
They dismissed it because of a no constitutional question at all so they did not hear it.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But your intermediate Court or whatever --

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: The Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: The Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: They overruled my motion to dismiss because there's not being a final order.
That is true.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And they have decided that for state purposes at any rate, this is a final order.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: And that I think they were wrong.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And what you're saying thus is that, they were wrong and we ought to overrule them on that question of state law or I suppose you'd have to say that as a matter of federal law, this is not a final order.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's our contention.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Even though the transfer order, the binding over order was self --it didn't involve any additional findings, did it?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Oh yes, it had to.
This Court does.
Sure it did.
This is -- that's when the Court makes his decision as to whether the bind over --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: What if the Juvenile Court fined that it hadn't found in connection with the delinquency.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No, it didn't find anything more in that regard.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's what I'm talking about.
I'm saying what makes you with the binding over order where any findings made by the Juvenile Court in addition to the findings that are before us right now.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Well, the Court -- the Court found based upon the investigation of the Juvenile Diagnostic Center that this boy was not mentally ill.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is that in the record?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No, it won't be because this was afterwards you see -- this was afterwards.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you have magistrates in Ohio.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Magistrates hearings in Ohio?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Yes, we do sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, suppose the magistrate binds the man over Grand Jury --

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would that be a final order?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: It would be a final order but it would not be an appeal of an order in our State.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what's the different between that when the Juvenile Court binds him over?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: With that, I think there's nothing -- there's no difference.
I quite agree with you that that would be a final order --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Don't your statute to provide that a juvenile has a right to proceedings in the Juvenile Court?
Does your statute say that or doesn't?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I didn't follow you sir.
I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Does the Ohio Statute provide that a juvenile has -- who is charged with an offense or whatever magic language you use that he has a right to be proceeded against in the Juvenile Court in the first instance?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Yes, he does have.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And so that here what's happened is a necessary and an adjudication of delinquency that according to your adversary anyway was necessary before the child could be deprived of his right to be preceded against in the juvenile and not the Adult Court.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Under our statute, the Juvenile Court has original, exclusive jurisdiction over all juveniles.
And a juvenile in our State is defined as the person being under the age of 18 years.
Our statute also says that a child cannot be found guilty of a crime in the Juvenile Court because he can only be charged with being a delinquent child in the Juvenile Court.
That's all.
The statute also gives our Juvenile Court exclusive, original jurisdiction over neglected, crippled or dependent children as well as delinquent children. It's all covered under the same statute.

So that if a person is charged with a crime -- for instance, suppose a 17-year-old child would be charge with a crime like in a Municipal Court or Police Court and if you brought it to the attention of the authorities that he was under 18 years of age, that would have to be immediately transferred to the Juvenile Court of the residence of the dependent.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: As my understanding, what we're dealing with here maybe a finding and an order by the Juvenile Court which in effect deprives the child of a right given to him under Ohio Law namely, the right to be tried in the juvenile and not in the adult Court.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No, no, it doesn't deprive the child of that right because the child or no one else has any as you say so except the Juvenile Court in cases of a felony.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I think I understand you but the point is, there has to be a Juvenile Court proceeding first before the child can be tried in the adult Court.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's right.
That is true.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Morehart may I ask, if the turnover order were before us and if we were to set it aside, what would be the effect upon the indictment?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: My opinion is that it would vacate the indictment unless of course, the ruling of this Court will be such as to say that the juvenile court out of the state of Ohio were unconstitutional.
If that we're true then I suppose it would be the juvenile where he was before that time, which would be the same as any other individual.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Subject to indictment.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's right.
I assume that to be true.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But apart from that --

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Apart from that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: On the hypothesis I gave you, the indictment would be invalidated and I gather this time would require a brand new Juvenile Court proceeding under whatever standard we set or to govern such procedures which might stand in up again I take it in a disposition which was a turnover order.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I assume that to be true. Now, that is my understanding of the law at this time.
Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did I understand you to say a while ago that the question of vagueness is upon in the Court of Appeals -- the right to be.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Well, only in the Common Pleas Court from the indictment and not in the Juvenile Court.
That is true.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is it pretty well settled in Ohio?
It used to be at my understanding was at least there used to be that the area of the first degree murder actually indicted the first degree murder that don't have any right to bail.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I know of no case in where they've held that if you have a right to bail on a first degree murder charge.
That's true.
That's my opinion of the law.
Yes sir.

I at this time -- now, we have said in our brief and we have argued here that the Juvenile Court -- that a person charged in a Juvenile Court that is a -- a juvenile is not entitled into a trial by jury.
Our statute in the State of Ohio provides that the juvenile judge shall hear the case informally against any child, not only delinquent but any neglected or crippled child.
He shall hear this informally as possible giving of course the defendant the right to be represented by counsel.
The right to summon witnesses of course and the right to cross-examination, and that statute now provides that an appeal shall be made.
And we have always assumed that that would include the right to make a transcript or a record of the proceedings.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Morehart, apart from the question of ultimate penalty, what are the benefits apart from the question of ultimate penalty, what are the benefits that Buddy Lynn Whittington received by reason of being tried in the Juvenile Court as against what would have happened to him in the Adult Court?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Well, if he would have been in the Adult Court until such time as he was indicted by the Grand Jury for first degree murder.
He would have been eligible for a bond because he hadn't been an adult.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I would have been an advantage of his being as an adult.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And so that's one thing on the deficit side is so far as the Ohio Juvenile Court system is concerned.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That is true --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He could have been released in the Juvenile Court too.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: He could have been.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Wouldn't the discretion have been the same?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No, I don't think the discretion would have been the same to be fair with you and honest with you, because I think a person charged with only a second degree murder and our State Courts as an adult is entitled to bail.
Now, it's a question then whether or not he would be a lot better off as a juvenile because the Court could release him without bond if he wanted to.
He could release him to his parents.
He could release him to another custodian.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: What you're telling us and we can pass to the next one is that if he had been an adult and he had been charged with exactly the same thing under Ohio and had been charged with second degree murder.
Under Ohio law, he would have had a right to bail.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Whereas being a juvenile, he was at the mercy of the judge.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And he did not get bailed.
What submits the advantage of the Juvenile Court procedure for this boy?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: The fact that he was now -- in this individual case, I suppose that you would have to say that it was disadvantage if he was being held when he could have been released to parents or probation officer or to someone else.
That's true and I suppose each individual case would have to depend entirely upon the merits and upon the judge as he saw fit.
Now, if the judge abused the discretion, there is always an appeal from that.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is there anything you can say that this boy got -- any benefit he got, any protection he got as a result of being processed or whatever you want to call it in the Juvenile Court as against being given the rights under our constitution in an adult Court.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Well from a practical standpoint, he was not held like an adult would be.
He was not confined in an adult jail.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That is not what the record -- what the opinion below says.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Well, he was not confined in a -- he was confined in the jail but not where they keep other adults.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That is contrary to what I've seen somewhere in this record.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: And he was not held in solitary confinement at no time.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Would you say that that isn't true?
That statement is made here.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: And they will find that the record is close.
His mother testified in one of this hearing that she was permitted to see the child at anytime or she and her husband that he had a television set in the room where he was.
And that he had magazines to read if he wanted to read that.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Where did this curious misapprehension that I can't spot it at the moment.
What's the basis of these curious statements in the papers before us?
Number one that the boy was kept along with adult prisoners, number two, that for a prolonged period of time, he was kept in solitary confinement.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I know of no such thing and I --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: You know that does appear.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That does appear and there is no basis for it that he was ever sentenced or kept in solitary confinement.
If ever he was alone is because there was no other juveniles to be confined with him and of course you can't go out on the street and arrest juveniles just to have company for someone that's there.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, this boy was not put in a special juvenile facility was he?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: It was a juvenile facility session we had at that time which is in upstairs over what our county jail is.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is that the eighth floor facility?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No sir, this is the second floor.
We only had two floors.
Now since that time, our commissioners have built a new jail and I assure you that it's been necessary for years and years and he is confined in different quarters now --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Are there any other benefits that this boy received by reason of the Ohio Juvenile Court procedures?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, he wasn't arrested for a crime in the first place, was he?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: He wasn't charged for the crime.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No sir.
Not under our law.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: He got no criminal record --

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: That's right.
That is true.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well apart from words what actually happened to the boy here, was he given any procedural rights that he would not get as an adult?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No.
I assume not any procedure right that an adult would not receive.
I think if that is true.
But now of course since that he has been transferred by the Juvenile Court to the Common Pleas Court then of course he is immediately closed with all the rights that an adult would have.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Because he has been transferred to the Common Pleas Court and there he will be treated as an adult.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Just because he was trying to refer it from Court to the other that he is the exact same person --

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: He is the exact same person but he is not charged with a crime before he was caught.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That makes it better.
He gets more rights having been charged with crime.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: No, I don't think that it makes it better.
I don't think so at all.
I think that he had a lot of rights.
Now you may say that the Juvenile Court abused the discretion in this case, and maybe that is true.
Maybe he should have been released.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Well, after the body was discovered, then the police who had been there and had gone home for dinner was recalled back of course.
And some of the emergency squad were there.
And the sheriff's office was called.
And they came there and I suppose at some place, they got there maybe around nine o'clock or a little after that time and they proceeded to make an investigation to call.
The coroner was called of course.
Pictures were made of the body and of the room where the body was found.
Questions were asked, both of Mr. and Mrs. Whittington in their own home and of the boy with the parents there at that time.
In fact another stranger was there.
I happened to be there at the time, and another person whom I do not know.
I assume that it might have been a relative.
I do not know up to this day.
I don't know.
The boy was never to my knowledge, has never been talked to by an official since that time by an officer.
But it is our --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How about a probation officer?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How about the probation officer?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I don't think that he has ever talked to him since that time sir, at least not about the experience.
I have no knowledge sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, what was the basis then for the arrest warrant?

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: The basis for the arrest warrant was the fact that this boy was here and he admitted that he had been here all the time.
And when we find out the cause of death from the pathologist and learned some more information about that fact, we assume that it had to be this boy that committed this crime.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He what?
I didn't --

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: I say that we assume that it had to be the boy who committed this crime.
That was the basis for a warrant issue or complaint being filed in the Juvenile Court by the chief of police.
Could I reserve -- I would like to reserve the rest of my time to Mr. Green.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: e_raymond_morehart
turn.label: Mr. E. Raymond Morehart
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Green.

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

Actually the turn of events here today is somewhat different that I had anticipated and I had intended I believe to pursue the line that I pursued when I was here in the Gault Case just to talk about the -- whether or not constitutionally, you can reasonably classify within the area of adults and minors.

And it's indicated to me by the Court's interest in this other factors that the philosophical problems that might be involved and the difference between children and adults may not be the thing that's foremost in your mind this time.
Aside from the particular facts in this case, I suppose that there is this overlaying questions as to -- role of the state the life of a child.
How much authority must or can the state have in the -- over the child's life.
In other words I have differences between children and adults such as to permit the procedures which are substantially different.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well Mr. Green, I have read your brief on behalf of the National Counsel of Juvenile Court judges.
I would like to ask you to address yourself to a question that I had put to Mr. Morehart.
Now, what did this boy, Buddy Lynn Whittington, get in terms of protection?
What if anything did he gets in terms of a protection of the state that he would not have gotten if he were tried in the adult Courts?

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: Well, we would have to assume at the outset because of the wide latitude given to the statute.
And almost universally followed that the judge is admonished almost the statute to release the child from custody to his parents or anybody else.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But he didn't get that did he?

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: That's right but I would say that we would have to assume I believe that because of either of the climate in the area or the nature of the crime with which he was charged, the Court in its wisdom whether it was right or not, felt that it would be better for Buddy Whittington to be retained in the custody of the Court or one of its officers.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Yes.
Now that the boy had been an adult or instead of being permitted to the discretion of the Juvenile Court judge, he had been an adult charged with second degree murder.
He would then have had a right to bail regardless of the --

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: There's no question about that under our law.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Alright, is there anything else that -- this boy.

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: This particular boy, I presume you could say, because of the entanglements of legal procedures that followed, nothing accrued to his benefit but that doesn't make the statue in it of itself unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, you tell me what could have accrued to his benefit once we pass this debate about what the judge might have done that he didn't do with respect to the release.

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: We'll have to make an assumption too that he came from a home that obviously to the Court indicated that to go back in that home it maybe the wrong thing for him.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I know nothing in this record.

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: That's right.
I said it Mr. Justice Fortas.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Let's don't assume that.
Let's talk about this boy.

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: This particular boy had nothing accrued to him that I can see on this record.
Actually, one of the things and I must say this, that's happened and this case has spent too much lowing in the case.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Maybe too much lowing at the wrong time and maybe not enough lowing in terms of basic structure.
What would you say to that Mr. Green?

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: The first part, I would say it was true.
Now I don't believe the basic structure in it of itself is the fault of any mishandling or any injustices done to Buddy Lynn Whittington.
Because you would almost have to assume that this is a routine matter of denying release from the custody of the Court to any juvenile who comes before the Court.
And I don't think there's any justification.
All the statistics available to the Court or this record to say that this was a routine handling Mr. Justice Fortas.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Do you disagree with the constitutional principle that provides for a right to bail?

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: No, by all means, I do not of course the constitutional principle is I believe stated in that.
It's about that no person shall be required to give excessive bail.

But I say and I only say this that I'm not contending that there should be two set of rules on the constitution, one for youngsters and one for adults, or that the constitution doesn't apply to everybody.
But I am suggesting that you can't properly create classifications taking into consideration the people for whom you're established in the classification.
It's not on -- to all of those children in the law have always been considered in a different like in adults.
Contracts for instance.

Like if you could just go on and name all of those things where children for reasons emotionally, biologically, mentally or whatever the reason maybe are distinguished from the adults and the different -- the law applies differently to them.
After all, the theory of the Juvenile Court's Law -- the Juvenile Court's trying to do.
I think the philosophy is there.
They're trying to find out when somebody or some youngster becomes entangled in the law what caused them to be entangled with the law?
And what can we do to either prevent him from going on to life occurring or what can we do to rehabilitate him as if he started?

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is there anything like that happened here so far as this record shows?

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: You mean as to this boy?
No.
Because he was prevented --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: What happened here?

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: What happened here in effect was an effort by the Juvenile Court to find out whether this boy committed the offense.
This terrible crime with what he was charged in substance if not in words.

And when it had for that purpose and without any of these attempts that we all talk about in connection with the Juvenile Court, to find out what kind of boy he is, what makes him take and what's the best thing to do with him, isn't that so?

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: No, I don't think that's true Mr. Justice Fortas.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Where do you find that in -- where do you find anything else in the record?

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: Well, his finding at the start, saying that there has been a murder committed.
There has been a killing.
The Court made these findings and said that it maybe that Buddy Whittington may have done.
And then along came -- in that same finding, he ordered the boy to be sent to the Youth Commission in Columbus for the various tests.
Now, it wasn't until after that on the basis of all these tests and a complete investigation the statute says.

That then he makes his determination whether he wants to keep him in giving this treatment that I'm talking about, or whether he wants to having found that the boy committed that backwards committed by an adult would have been a felony.
Not necessarily it's a felony.
But then he makes a determination whether he should make the boy available to -- the resources of community or whether or not he should be tried as an adult.
So you see this part of it was cut off really by the State of this record.
I should point out that one statement of fact that it's apparently little different.
And that is that the time between the hearing in September and he was bound over because I really truly believe that this was a preliminary matter.
It was only about seven months.
I think it was from September.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: In your brief, you referred to that as shameful incarceration of this boy.

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: I believe shameful treatment.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Shameful treatment.

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: That's right.
The point was that -- I don't believe that he followed the system.
You see because from the time this boy had a hearing one month after he was arrested.
And I think the record would show that that delay even, some of it is on at the request of the boy's lawyer.
And from that time on, the Court was stopped, prevented from acting.
Until after this Court in preparation for filing a petition refused to stay any longer than the Grand Jury.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: At which state the juvenile judge could have left it in the juvenile authority?

turn.speaker: merritt_w_green
turn.label: Mr. Merritt W. Green
turn.text: At that time, yes.
That's right, Your Honor.
That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Another question that I will -- thank you for your attention.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Rezneck.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and May it please the Court.
If I may say just one further word on the finality question, I would just like to specify the dates here for the Court that the petition for certiorari was filed on April 11, 1967.
And the binding over order of the Juvenile Court was on April 24, 1967.
And it occurred during this period of time when there was no longer a stay in effect as to further Juvenile Court proceedings.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's before we acted on the petition, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Yes, you granted.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Any reason why we weren't asked to act down the petition in respect to the turnover.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Well, at that time, the turnover -- when certiorari was filed for the turnover, the transfer order had not been entered.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, but after it was and before we acted on the petition, it was a long interval before we acted on the petition.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: I believe that the record will show that there was a request for a state --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You have said that and I've looked for it with no success.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Well, it's not in the current record that I have here but it maybe in the file.
My understanding is that there was an order by this Court which denied the stay of further proceedings.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: We denied a stay?

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Yes you did.
So you have this in the regular period when these proceedings were unable to go forth below.

With respect to the question of finality, I would like to direct the Court's attention to a decision by this Court in the case of New York Ex Rel Bryant v. Zimmerman, which we've decided on page 5 of our reply brief which involved a petition for writ of habeas corpus in advance with trial by someone who was under indictment.
And the petition for habeas corpus was denied at the State Courts and review was sought in the Supreme Court of United States while they were still depending indictment in the State Courts.
And this Court held that that was a final judgment.
That the habeas corpus proceeding is independent, adversary and both adapted, and directed to the enforcement of a most important personal right and to entertain that appeal.

And we think that the same situation prevails here with the juvenile proceeding which was an independent proceeding and which did end in the adjudication of delinquency with very serious consequences for the juvenile.
We think Mr. Morehart is simply asking this Court to reverse the decision of the Courts of Ohio as to the appealability of this order under state law.
With respect to the evidence --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it is a separate question for finality with its final progress.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Yes and I believe in that question, you look at the incidents of the judge --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What would have happened in the Juvenile Court if the Court had decided when the -- when it was permitted to go forward that it wouldn't -- that the Court would not turnover.
What order would have been --?

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Well, it would have had a variety of dispositional orders open to it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it's still a disposition order to be entered.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Well, there was a disposition order here, there would have been a further order which could have been still temporary in nature or which could have been a permanent commitment, which could have been probation, which could have been a fine.
They have this continuing jurisdiction and they could modify their orders even from time to time so that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But there are still in this case necessarily -- at least another order had to be entered one way or another.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: There's no specific provision of course requiring the Court to do that or even setting a time limit within which the Court --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Once the diagnostic center send it back -– is that the statute there?

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Well a statute doesn't say to the contrary that there is no provision in the statute which is comparable to the provision of the federal criminal rule.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: A common sense would indicate that perhaps there was another order coming.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: I would have thought that the judge would have to do something or else it would be susceptible to habeas corpus.
On the evidentiary point which Mr. Morehart had talked about, I would like to just direct the Court's attention to page 271 of the record which is a critical passage in the Court of Appeals opinion.

The Court below affirm this judgment by the use of the civil standard but they also had at the statement which we submit must have been considered with great care that the evidence contained in the record fails to disclose any thorough investigation by officials toward eliminating the possibility that Mrs. Gladys Willard may have been killed by some other person.

Mr. Morehart says that he assumes that the boy did it and I submit that that is all you have here in assumption and not based on any tolerable standard of guilt when liberty and reputation are at stake.
And that is not a sufficient basis to impose the kind of sanctions that are available here.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: -- you understand it under which the judge decided that the man is a delinquent man.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: As I understand in Ohio, he is entitled to do on a basis of a preponderance of the evidence as if it were an ordinary garden variety negligence of --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: What must they prove about it to prove that he a delinquent?

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: In this case where the violation of a criminal statute was involved, they must simply prove by a preponderance of the evidence that he violated the criminal statute.
And that's sufficient to adjudicate in the delinquent.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: What's the standard to bind over an adult to a Grand Jury for a trial?

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: The state statute I believe refers to substantial and credible evidence.
2937.13 says that the Court while weighing the credibility witness shall not be required to pass on the weight of the evidence.
Any finding requiring the accused to stand trial on any charge shall be based solely under presence of substantial credible evidence thereof.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: On the presence of substantial --

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Without weighing it.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Yes which is even a lower standard than the preponderance standard?

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Rezneck, Mr. Morehart challenged the statement that's been made about a boy being confined and along with adult and being in solitary confinement.
What do you say to that?

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: I'd like to direct the Court's attention on the first point on the adult confinement to page 253 of the record which is the journal entry of the District Court of Appeals, which ordered Buddy released from the confinement, and in which he was then held in the adult jail.

After a personal view and I said from our view, we find that Buddy is confined in a portion of the jail used for adults and that an adult is now in fact confined in an adjoining cell in the same room.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That was after a personal viewing by the Court.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: That was personal viewing by the Court of Appeals.
With respect to the solitary, it was repeatedly asserted and never denied in motions for release to the Court that he was being held in solitary.
There's no evidence that anyone else was confined with him and any other juvenile and I would direct the Court's attention to the testimony of his mother that's up here.
It's at page 99 of the record in which she was asked to have an opinion as to what continued and enforced incarceration in that cell as to whether it would affect Buddy's mental well being.
And she answered, “Yes sir.
I think anybody being penned up like that by themselves for as long as he has been – or as long as he might have to be.
I think even myself or even an adult that would work on your mind it couldn't help but do that just penned up there all day long.”
And then she said in response to a further question.
Well, when he sits there all day long, sometimes he doesn't say much when we go in.
I think his mind might be dulled by being there.
There's nothing for him to do, just sit there.
It would affect your mind to or anybody's.
So we think that there's an ample predicate.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: May I ask you one more question about those two pieces of evidence?

Suppose they are both truth or suppose he was kept in solitary confinement –- suppose he was kept in a place that had -- what effect should that have on our view of the finding that he was a delinquent?

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Well, I realized that this creates a problem as to what remedy would be affected at this time after he has been found to be a delinquent.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Would that authorize us or justify us by setting aside the judgment finding that he is a delinquent.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: We think that it would, Your Honor but for the denial of a fundamental constitutional right --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That is a denial of the fundamental constitution right you would say.
That's the way he's kept in jail.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: You're right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do you think that should set aside the finding that he is a delinquent.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: The right to be from cruel and unusual punishment such as this boy was projected to as a fundamental constitutional right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now we should order him completely released at all time because he was kept in a solitary confinement.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: We think it should invalidate the proceedings against him with respect to whether he can be retried.
We think that question turns on the resolution of the standard of proof and the sufficiency of the evidence under a constitutional standard.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So what is the efficiency of the proof of the question of delinquency had to do with where he is kept in jail.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Those two questions are not related Your Honor.
I'm not saying that because he was subjected to cruel and unusual punishment that he cannot be retried.
I think that he could be retried if that were the only ground that we had.
I am saying that I think the procedures carried on below are sufficiently --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's kind of -- when is it addressed?

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: Well, it's our last argument, Your Honor.
I hesitate to call --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well Mr. Rezneck, it has been urged before us in this case and it's been otherwise urged that the State has a burden of showing that the classification of children for purposes of various applications of its laws is a reasonable one and in terms of justification of denial of certain rights, certain constitutional rights.
And it's been urged that for the State to bear that first, it's got to show a wide range of factors to indicate that the classification is reasonable.
And among those factors is the question of what the State does with respect to the child.
It makes it reasonable for the State to classify the child separately and differently with respect to the administration of its law of offenses including their things of which juveniles are charged.
And from that point of view, it's urged that the question of facilities or no facilities available for special treatment of juveniles is relevant to the constitutional question.

The State that to you not to reflect my own view on it because I don't at the moment have a view on that but as making quite relevant, as an argument, that would if valid to make quite relevant to the question of what does the State do with respect to juveniles to justify the separate classification in this separate system of jurisprudence, that it can be so called.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: I would certainly say that the State is going to try juvenile's criminals, confine them as criminals, and punish them as criminals that it cannot obey constitutional obligations by -- pardon me?
Confine them as criminals, punish them, impose punishment on them as criminals that it can't.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think it's relevant on the issue of whether or not this delinquency judgment -- to base it in that finding in anyway on whether this fellow was brought and was kept in jail.

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: We think our arguments that go to the invalid fact finding procedure will amply dispose off this point and will show the invalidity of the juvenile delinquency adjudication, Your Honor.
We're not relying on the punishment factor solely to invalidate the delinquency of finding.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: No it does not Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: daniel_a_rezneck
turn.label: Mr. Daniel A. Rezneck
turn.text: The record is silent on that.
For these reasons, we pray that the judgment below be reversed.
Thank you very much.
